Operating Incident, 22/09/2020, An RRV cherry picker being used in connection with engineering work on the Island Line became derailed at Sandown siding approximately 40 metres from where it had been placed on the rails. The operator had sustained an injury to their arm. Initial investigations indicated a possible issue with the RRV because one of the front wheels was 2 inches of the rail. The fitter reported that everything was working fine with self-levelling of the wheels, but it could be seen that when the machine was heading back to "off track" the wheel still wasn’t touching the rail and got stuck and couldn’t move. Even when the machine was stable and ready to "off track", the wheel was not touching the rail by 20mm. If the self-levelling part of the machine was working, the wheel that was in the air should have been touching the head of the rail. There was no damage to any off the track because it only travelled about 30 to 50 meters.

Operating Incident, 21/10/2020, During a shunt move between number 3 and 16 roads (via number 4 road) on Bournemouth Train Care Depot involving the class 73 loco, it was found that number 49 points had been run through, which had been plugged and clipped during a possession. The issue was realised as the loco was travelling over the points. The possession had been given up to allow the shunt to take place, but due to miscommunication between the shunter and the contractors, the points had been missed. Investigations are still on going.

Prior to the unit being aux'd off, the DP procedure was already being commenced with the batteries being isolated, and the shoegear isolation switch turned into the shore supply position. Near Miss, 09/06/2021, During a traction current isolation taken by Sonic Rail Team, a section of track was observed as going live at Farnham Traincare Depot. The isolation was given at 09:59 and the event took place at 10:13. Sonic Rail Team were working on a Track Disconnector 9072 and the ECRO reports the contractor team were working on a padlock and claim to have made the track live during this operation. It is suspected that the lock for TD9072 is defective which meant that the AP had difficulty closing the lock.  No injuries or damage to infrastructure has been reported. The isolation was handed back to the ECRO and TD9072 was taken out of use.

Person on Board When Train Departed, 27/08/2021, A passenger was carried into the sidings at Poole on the stock which had formed 1B21 1035 Waterloo - Poole. The passenger was brought back into the station when the stock returned for hits return working. The train was formed of a 10 car 444 set, with the booked units being 444012 and 444044. The guard had patrolled through the train prior to its arrival at Poole and counted the number of passengers onboard. The guard had also made a number of announcements to advise that the train would be terminating at Poole. The guard had counted all the passengers off, however the passenger who was found after it had departed ECS for the sidings, had reboarded the train at the last minute to use the toilet. The guard did check the train after they had locked the doors, but did not walk the whole way through.

Operating Incident, 02/12/2021, "During a shunt move on Wimbledon Traincare Depot, 5R05 0525 Wimbledon Depot - Waterloo was believed to have passed W1124 signal on number 1 road at danger. The train was formed of a 10 car 458 set was being driven by a trainee under instruction. The driver had been given permission to proceed to W1135 signal, change ends and to exit the depot via W1124 and W1123 signals. However, on reaching W1135 signal, the train had not pulled close enough to the signal to clear the track circuit to clear W1124 signal. On changing ends, the front of 5R05 was ahead of W1124 signal, the driver saw that W1123 signal was displaying a proceed aspect and proceeded towards the signal without getting permission from the signal to proceed from W1124. Booked units were 458510 & 458528. "

After viewing the CCTV footage this morning you can see the person ride and walk up and down roman road (the rear of time guard and Lidl)for 5 to 10 mins until they climb over the fence facing plot 4 after gaining access to the site, they walk casually into plot 3 checking the workers cabins, machines and storage containers they can be seen picking up multiple orange PPE vests before going out of CCTV view towards a storage container and gaining access to multiple tools and workers equipment, this went on for around 30 minutes walking back and forth from plot 3 and surrounding areas until they finally climbed over the fence and leaving via Roman road with the stolen items.

description: Staff Accident - 07/12/2023 17:00:00 Other Contact. A member of Fleet Staff cut their thumb on the coupling tool

"Following an OLE dewirement on Network Rail Great Western Mainline at 1830, Train 9R14 became stranded on the RfLI Westbound Departure Road as the overhead line traction supply (fed by NR) was subject to an emergency switch off. A plan was formulated by the RfLI Service & Infrastructure Manager (SIM) to send an empty rescue train to draw alongside 9R14 via Turnback A and carry out an indirect train-to-train transfer of the approx 1000 passengers on board. The rescue train (with approx 14 railway staff on board) arrived on Turnback A at 20:10. The rescue party observed a train ahead and incorrectly thought that this was 9R14 and made their way to the train. This was in fact 9T12, which the rescue party commenced detraining. On returning towards the rescue train at approx 2210, the party observed passengers approaching from 9R14 who had self-evacuated from the train. The rescue party, then realised that they had not noticed 9R14 and commenced detraining this train to Westbourne Park Road Rail Access Point."

The member of staff advises these points are normally clipped and scotched in reverse for moves into the down yard. Then clipped and scotched normal for moves into the Colas fueling Point. The GSTM advises that he failed to properly observe the points at this juncture and this has lead to the derailment.

Report received from Maybank Security that "On patrol at 12:00 while checking outside perimeter on zone 4, towards Mayfield Gate I found a breach under the fence. There was a pallet leaning on the outside of the fence and a deep hole that had been dug underneath, and covered up with sticks and cloth. I decided to secure the area by filling the hole with my shovel from the van, to finish with the incident straight away and prevent anyone getting access. at 16:20 on patrol along zone 4, moving inside perimeter going towards Mayfield Gate 4, I came across some new Graffiti on the scrap carriages/containers, being stored down there by DB. I have taken pics as its highly likely the site was entered by the earlier perimeter breach found at 12:00. This area for both incidents is massively overgrown and not visible, also there is no CCTV. I will advise extra vigilance."

It has then been distributed to the Signalling team to commence works in the Sidings and they have proceeded to the works. Operational Incident - 31/08/2024 01:00:00 Operating Incident. 1 Road traction dolly rope was broken at Bournemouth Depot during a shunt move.

[Robel Deutzer Shorting Live AC OLE - Pan Raised without Authority] At approx. 01:57 Saturday, the duty ODM noticed a huge flash from Plumstead Depot window. Immediately, enquires were done to discover the cause. After conversations and discussions with various stakeholders, it was determined that the FDS4 measuring equipment on the Robel had encounter the Live wire when the Robel was traveling to the site of work. The equipment has a separate Pentagraph which is reported to be allowed to raise up to 1 meter away from the overhead line equipment to conduct measuring. The operator raised the Pentagraph fully, connecting with the live OLE causing a trip which resulted in the flash. It has been reported that all the measuring equipment connected to the Robel is damaged and not fit for use. It was then decided to keep the electricity off and return the Robel back into the maintenance 09 road to berth. Once the machine was berthed and clear, actions were taken to inspect the damage caused to the infrastructure. The OLE such as wires, structures, droppers, and rail was all assessed from the OLE track technician. It was confirmed to only have minor dis-colourisation but no concerns to for normal operations of the railway thereafter. All staff involved were stood down and cause for screening followed. Incident number (Safe) – 3906.

description: It has been reported at 07:20 Sunday (01/09/2024), a stop marker board had been left out on track at Plumstead Sidings number one. The incident response manager attended site and took a line block to retrieve the marker board. Checking that nights possession details (week 23 Saturday night) - a possession was in place, item 04 with locations between Westbourne Park / Pudding Mill Lane / Abbey Wood (Plumstead Sidings). The published possession limit for this location was beyond XR501 mark point, the same location a stop board was found to be placed. Incident control report: SAFE 9313 | 07:20 | Plumstead, Sidings 1 | Stop board marker • 3P38 reports a stop board marker in front of the train impeding its departure. CCTV viewed, and board marker is seen in front of the unit. • Amendment for affected unit to later form 3P98 due out at 14:00 hours. • IRM on scene performed a line block with TM1. • Item removed and line handed back at 0956

Copied from XXXXXXX XXXXX statement email: my name is XXXXXXX XXXXX  (Track Team). I am not coming in tonight as I had a accident last night at WBP. My job was to scope the whole WBP area for ballast work with my principal XXXXXXX. Because of rain we cancelled our job as we couldn't see the dusty ballast for voids. As it was raining then we decided to help XXXX XXXXXX and XXXXXX with their BVI-24, loose and missing clips and removal of lane 6 signs from WB. After finishing all the jobs, myself and XXXX picked up the signs from turnback A and started walking back to ROP. On the way back I saw few lids were off from the troffins next to turnback A and decided to put them back on for everyone's safety. XXXXXXX and I made them safe. As XXXXX(ODM) as Lookout and XXX (COSS) witness this as they were walking behind us. Then I picked up the sign and started walking again and few metres away, my left foot went through another troffin which looked visibly fine to walk over while carrying the sign which was little heavy. When I fell down and my left knee landed on the ballast. On that moment it was sore and I had bleeding. We walked back and cleared the work site. We returned to Plumstead and after finishing my shift when I went home and took my PPE off then I saw my PPE was covered with blood and by then it was painful. I bandaged it, took few pain killers, and went to sleep. When I woke up my knee was stiff and painful as it is internal injury. So, I will be resting my knee. Can you please put this in the accident book for me and forward me the copy as well. I have informed my seniors as well. Thanks.

Belated Incident report emailed from National Security Lead to advise the following suspicious circumstances " At 13:01:38 while monitoring POC's Control Room spotted an IC1 male outside the sliding gate at DB Knottingley who was looking into site using binoculars. Male was in casual attire consisting of blue hoodie, blue jeans and grey beanie cap. Male arrived on a white Hyundai with registration "L55 RES". After taking a peek into site using his binoculars he disappeared from the through road which leads to sliding gate and went towards the main road. POC Control Room believes that he went towards the back side of the site. At 13:10:49 he was again seen in RDC 47's visual and was again looking into site Police (999) was called at 13:03 and POC Control Room requested to be put through to the West Yorkshire Police. Upon getting connected to the West Yorkshire Police all details about the individual, his vehicle, about his activity and about site were passed to the Police's operator. DB Knottingley's name and phone number were also given to the police as police asked for name and number of the site's keyholder. Incident reference number given by West Yorkshire Police is #1018. While POC's Control Room Operator was still on phone with West Yorkshire police, at 13:12 a text was sent to West Yorkshire SAM on WhatsApp to make him aware of a suspicious activity outside the sliding gate. SAM asked for photos to be sent to him. After seeing the photos SAM replied "Looks like a train enthusiast trying to read the loco numbers on the shed front looking at it!". A text was sent to British Transport Police on 61016 with the site address, what 3 words and what was actually happening outside the site. They asked for more details through text message and all relevant details were sent through text message. Incident reference number was provided by British Transport Police through text message which is #388. At 13:13:33, suspicious individual left the area in his vehicle.

The PICOP for Item 07 and the ES for Worksite [W2024/11168618] informed the duty ODM that the planned rail replacement works have been abandoned due to concerns raised regarding the dust/fumes levels in the area. The works involved cutting concrete in preparation for the welding points and re-rail activities scheduled during upcoming blockade. Despite adequate PPE being worn (face masks), the task could not proceed as there were additional concerns that the fumes emanated by the cutting machines would not only cause harm, but could have also triggered the fire alarms. The ODM has checked the ventilation planned and identified that there was no ventilation in the area - this situation requires escalation as the task is not safe to resume without appropriate control measures in place.
